text: A modern house, packed with dark-clad figures, clings to edge of a precipice. Its lights are blurred in the sort o fog that Angelenos call a marine layer. In the road that curves past and below the house, VALETS silently taking and parking (driving off to park) expensi cars. Valets in their white shirt-fronts are running up a down the road. The people going up to the house do not seem to be party- goers: they are all male, mostly grave, primarily Asian businessmen. A fogged view of the valet area is revealed by a sudden s of WIPERS. We reverse to see: A BMW 1 series, the 1M, the orange killer, standing pulle over against the curb, under a spray of somebody's bougainvillea. The car is idling. It contains only the driver.

A BRASS ZIPPO lighter is clicked open, shut, open, shut. The driver, JIM — the gambler of the piece — is watching house. Close on his calculating eyes. The LIGHTER clicks open, shut, open, shut, and then a decision is made: JIM puts the lighter in the pocket of h dark suit, and gets abruptly out of the car.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE STREET IN THE HOLLYWOOD HILLS. NIGHT

text: JIM walks downhill towards the valet area. He is tall, we dressed, thirty five. He needs a shave, he’s tieless, and looks like he might have been up for five days straight, he has decent style, a natural suavity. A FILIPINO VALET notes him, and the car.
You bring car here.
Already got a space, buddy. He looks up at the LIGHTED HOUSE, then at the VALET.

I’ve got a lucky face. THE VALET stares, authority challenged, flummoxed, as JIM, with a glance back, goes up the steep stairs under flaring torches. In the undergrowth we see (and JIM sees) that a FOR SALE has been toppled over, and badly hidden. After following JIM briefly through the gardens, over the brick paths, and past big SECURITY MEN (multi-ethnic), on whom nods as JIM appears, we go to JIM'S POV to enter the house, to move through the packed rooms. There is a girl inside with a GUEST LIST. She know him, makes a mark. The rooms, done up around the edges as a temporary bottle service gambling club, are full of serious gamblers. Agai mostly Asian, but with some serious casuals, a few hip- hoppers. It’s a catered affair. The same sort of casually employed actors and models and students that move around drinks and food on trays at any party in Hollywood. JIM moves through the rooms, noting... TABLE AFTER TABLE, all of them in heavy play, by very hea gamblers. Through a door, apart, we see a POKER GAME going on, heav hitters. JIM moves on, observing everything, ready for anything, looking for what he needs, the game he needs. A STUDENT-WAITRESS (AMY), for a moment, might be it: but after making serious eye contact, and a moment in which J and AMY register each other without affect, and he shakes head very slightly to reject either a canape or something much more complicated, she moves on through the crowd. He keeps moving. She keeps moving. They seem to know each other from another context, and it rattled Jim, to see her here. Near the MONEY changing hands at an improvised CAISSE, wh a woman in specs trades colored plaques for cash in the A casino manner, KOREAN HEAVIES stand guard, earpieced, arm (The security guys outside are any security guys: the inn sanctum is Korean). JIM goes to the caisse table, reaches into his coat, and pulls out ten thousand-odd dollars in a wrapper. He waits watches, as  His MONEY is counted... And as... THE PLAQUES are shoved across. As JIM gathers up the plaques and puts them in his coat, notices an older, tough, grave, civil, unreadable Korean MISTER LEE, looking at him carefully.
You do better tonight. JIM nods.

Couldn’t do worse. They look at each other. JIM has his game face: but MISTE LEE always has his. MISTER LEE nods, and, though it’s sub allows JIM to pass on through into the big, crowded, high ceilinged room.

head_text.subj: INT. THE BLACKJACK AREA. NIGHT. LATER

text: SPECTATORS are watching. MISTER LEE moves up to watch. JIM, the only player at the table, with at least eight ti more plaques in front of him than we saw him buy, absolut intent on the game, shoves 40K in plaques forward and is dealt a CARD DOWN and a JACK UP. JIM checks his down card and sees a 4, and looks up at th dealer, like a duellist marking his man. The DEALER (KOREAN, an at-sea family man who really shoul be doing this, really shouldn't be in these circumstances realizes he’s in it, and is very nervous.

Double down, make it twenty thousand. The DEALER looks over at MISTER LEE, who nods his approva JIM gets a king. He’s lost. His on-table pile is raked aw He smiles, and then deliberately, enjoying it, he pushes the last of his RESERVED CHIPS...all of them.

(to uncertain, sweating dealer) Mister Lee can cover a lot more than that, buddy. (a beat) You must be new. MISTER LEE again has to nod his approval. The sweating DEALER deals. JIM is given a card down and a 2 showing. The DEALER has queen showing. JIM looks at him again, briefly; then flip his down card, sees a 7, and tucks it under his 2. After catching the eye of the passing...
In the crowd...

(off something about Amy) Let’s go for it, brother. (this means something about Amy) Double it. JIM takes a card down, flicks it up with his 7 card. It i ace. He is unmoved. The DEALER turns up his down card, a 5; then draws a 6 fo 21. We stay on the cards long enough to count them. JIM'S COUNTERS are scraped away by the house. MISTER LEE moves indifferently away through the crowd.

JIM is entirely without affect: as if losing money was exactly what he wanted: to be done with it. He pulls out a single RED 500 dollar counter, looks at it turns it in his hand, in the well-done light, puts it bac his pocket. A bejeweled COURTLY GANGSTA (NEVILLE) beside him (and his POSSE never far from Neville):
I hope you paid your rent, homes. JIM looks at him, perfectly capable of either glassing h walking away.
I don’t pay rent. Homes. After this (ambiguity) is taken on board:
You got a problem, an issue of some kind?
Yeah, I don’t like your fuckin’ hat. JIM is quite obviously a gambler in many aspects of life. NEVILLE and POSSE exchange glances. DANGEROUS KOREANS hav moved in at the hint of trouble.
(quietly to Neville’s ear) I think you kinda want me to have an issue, so I thought of that one. JIM tosses down his drink, chews his ice, and stares at Neville.
I got plenty of issues. A dangerous guy in a hat's only one of them. What's yours?
See you outside, motherfucker. JIM turns back and spreads his arms.
Well, we all gotta go out sometime. It's never when you want it and it's always gonna hurt. (turns back, leans in) You a gambler?
Not like you.
You don't know what I am. That's the first thing you should know. JIM looks intently at him, inches away.
You want to fuck around or do you want to cut cards for 500? NEVILLE looks at him, at the raised 500 PLAQUE.
I put ten grand against your five hundred. Is that gambler enough for you?
I haven’t got ten grand. That’s an unequal bet. The courtly NEVILLE indicates his smoldering POSSE:
It’s an unequal general situation. JIM appreciates that.

Oh, I like odds. (holding out palm to the wide-eyed DEALER, not looking at him) Give us a deck. One is shuffled. JIM takes it, walks with Neville to a ne small bar where champagne is set up, puts the deck down, nods at NEVILLE who cuts first and shows...with great reluctance.... The KING OF SPADES. JIM, amused, looks up at NEVILLE who is not amused at all
That’s funny.

I thought you wanted my business card. The deck is reshuffled and JIM cuts, revealing, and takin to look at, a JACK OF HEARTS. AMY is watching. JIM looks at her: and then looks down. She turns away.  JIM tosses the card on the table and holds out the 500 marker.
(genuinely) Congratulations. He holds out his hand and NEVILLE takes THE PLAQUE and ha over in return a glass of champagne. JIM takes a small si and sets the glass aside.
I seen you around. I think you like to lose.
Life’s a losing proposition, right? Might as well get it over with. He starts off.
(over his shoulder) You need a stake? JIM turns.
You like staking losers? NEVILLE has no response.
I know how you stake people.

Then you know everything. He sips his drink and loses interest. JIM moves away, now broke. (KOREANS watching him, one KOR aside talking to MISTER LEE). He goes to a SIDEBOARD load with BUFFET FOOD, and realizes he’s famished. He loads a plate, loads it, and carries it out onto the terrace.

AMY looks briefly out through the window at the oblivious JIM, concerned, intrigued, and then moves on with her TRA CANAPES. JIM puts the plate on the terrace rail and starts to wolf food. As we come around,  MISTER LEE materializes behind him.
Your luck is no good these days. JIM brasses this out:
Maybe. MISTER LEE is intrigued by this guy.
You came in with ten thousand in cash. I don't know where you got it.
Oh, I think we can be pretty sure it was from gambling.
Wherever you got it, you didn't give it to me.
No, I didn’t.
Why not?
This is a gambling establishment.

You have a family? A wife? Children? JIM shakes his head “no”. (Though this is a lie and a tru simultaneously). MISTER LEE looks as if this explains ple which it may well do. (Though it doesn’t). JIM stares out over the canyon, comes to an abrupt, brass-balled decisio
Well, that depends if you give me ten thousand more in credit.
You owe a lot of money.
Everybody owes money all over the place. Have I never not paid you?

Eventually, a debt gets too big to pay. Then...no one is responsible. JIM grips the rail of the porch. Down in the LOWER GARDEN PROSTITUTES do business by the pool, one or another going with a businessman into the dark. A freshly unfolded aspe of Hell. All whispers into ears. As JIM watches...

Some people find impossibility to pay a relief. Their lives...are out of their hands. (closer, as on Feisal in Lawrence) I think you may be one of those people. JIM takes it on. Maybe what Mister Lee said is what he’s after — maybe it isn’t. TWO BIG KOREANS (the key ones, intelligent muscle) are now with MISTER LEE.
But all this...is starting to be over. JIM looks at him.
Get me my money. MISTER LEE walks away, his MUSCLE following. JIM leans back with his elbows on the rail, stretching hi back, looking at the stars, and then looks over and sees:
NEVILLE now on the terrace, lying back in a deck chair, smoking a COHIBA, his boys seated in shadow nearby.
A shadow falls across NEVILLE. He looks up. We reverse to see: JIM.
Stake me fifty grand. A long look from NEVILLE.  10.
At twenty points.
At whatever points you like. We had a conversation about odds. You think I mind them?

(to associate) Give him fifty grand. (to JIM) Make sure my man has your, ah, digits, and so forth. A DESIGNER LEATHER BAG is dug into. JIM takes CASH, in te grand bundles, and goes over to the surprised MISTER LEE. shows the money.

You can take the whole fifty, and we'll settle up — but as we discussed, this is a gambling establishment. MISTER LEE keeps his counsel; then keeps forty, hands it BIG KOREAN, and hands ten grand back to Jim with a grave JIM pockets the ten. JIM walks past the smoking, disinterested NEVILLE.
Bonne chance.
I feel better about your hat. But not about you wearing it inside. NEVILLE looks after him. His GUYS stand up.
Sit down.
JIM trades the ten in cash for plaques, then heads (AMY a picking him up with her eyes) for the Blackjack table. JIM pushes all his markers in. The whole ten grand.

Do it. No no. Don’t look at Mister Lee. You look at me. Do it.  11. The DEALER deals. JIM gets a queen showing. The Dealer has an ace showing. checks his down card and sees a 3. He nods for a card and hit with an 8 for 21.
Twenty one. The DEALER turns over an 8, making 20, and Jim has won. H could cash out now, and big, but he leaves his winnings d and says:

Play the two. The DEALER gives JIM a 10 up and another card down; deals himself a king up. JIM flips and sees another 10 for 20. dealer draws two cards — and busts. Jim’s won again. JIM nods for the DEALER to start another hand. The DEALER looks at MISTER LEE.

He doesn’t want you to look at him. Deal the cards. SPECTATORS crowd around. NEVILLE is watching. AMY comes through the crowd and SHE is watching. The DEALER gives JIM a down card and an 8. He deals himse 4 showing over his down card. JIM sees his down card is a
(to DEALER) You take it. The DEALER turns over a 2, then draws a jack for 16 and t a queen to bust. Jim wins with a 10 for 14. MISTER LEE watches. The DEALER looks at MISTER LEE.
Don’t look at him. There’s no limit.
It's for your own protection.
Fuck my protection. You don’t come here for fucking protection from yourself. (MORE )

You come here for the fuckin’ opposite and here I am. Deal the cards. MISTER LEE nods. THE CARDS ARE DEALT. JIM wins another hand with 21. He takes up the counters. Turns away, goes, with people watching him, Amy watching to... The roulette table. JIM stands and looks at the waiting table, magic in the l over it. He puts down his plaques. NEVILLE has come up be him.
Everything on black.
Red's been coming up all night.
You want me to pay you now? Is that what you want me to do?
No.
Why not?
Because you’1ll either lose and you're mine for talking shit about my headgear, or either I want to just watch the show.
It’s all of those things.
Yeah.
What about ripping me off outside if I win?
Not in that business, brother.  13.
Everything on black. The ball rolls, and it’s nearly black, but then the ball lands in...

The CROWD reacts as if a man has just dropped from a scaffold. AMY, in the crowd, turns away. JIM leans with h elbows on the table for a minute: but then stands straigh look NEVILLE in the eye. NEVILLE looks at JIM.
Float me some spending money. NEVILLE gives him a thousand dollars.

That's at twenty points, too. JIM folds away the money. He looks at NEVILLE. He looks a MISTER LEE. Then he goes, pushing his way through the cro as those people look after him who still have the interes do so.

head_text.subj: EXT. STREET IN THE HOLLYWOOD HILLS. DAWN

text: JIM comes down the steps, looks bleakly at the valets, an then walks up to his car. The sun is rising, lighting the shoulder of the hill beyond the Hollywood sign.

JIM sits in his car, exhausted, defeated, taking shit on, barely holding it together. He watches NEVILLE and his PO pile into two Bentleys and drive off down the canyon. The puts the car in gear and drives.

JIM pulls up to the Seventh Veil, and in one long shot ge out of the car and heads in, handing the doorman a 20, mo through the dark room, avoiding the “dancers” (it’s been long time since strip clubs in Los Angeles haven't been brothels) until he comes to one in particular, a beautifu black Amazon in a yellow bikini. She starts to do the thi the come-on (stripper ad-libs)...
You a tourist, baby?  But Jim holds up his hand and stops her.
We're all tourists. It's the nature of the planet. She starts to speak.

Listen. I don’t need you to talk. I need you to listen to me. No. No no, you listen. I know it’s hard, I know you want to talk your bullshit, but if you do, I’m going to leave. 14. She nods, maybe getting it. He holds out a hundred dollar bill. She looks at it: starts to speak: but he stops her.

I don’t want you to act like you’re in a porn film made for retards, because there’s no girl in here better looking than anybody I've ever even gone out with once, so I want you to act like a normal woman with no mental problems and then I want you to take this hundred dollars, I want you to take me in back, where you blow people for money, and I want you to do what I ask you to do without saying another fucking word to me ever again in my life. Can you do that? Because if you can’t shut up I can’t stay here. Finally she nods and takes the hundred dollar bill.
OK. All right. He follows her into the back room as if marching to a dea sentence and we go to:

Establish a part of the college, with JIM’S CAR parked erratically in the foreground. STUDENTS and STAFF on the grounds of the campus like figures in a painting.  15. INT. ENGLISH DEPT FACULTY MEN’S ROOM. DAY JIM is splashing his face with water. He’s still not shav His white collar is now not clean. Out of one of the toil comes an English Department ASSHOLE (JONES). Basically FD without the wheelchair, senior to Jim, and not as good on subject. He washes his hands.
First time I've ever seen you without a shave.
I’m trying to avoid tenure. You can have that one.
If I could teach like you I'd be a little more grateful. JIM examines him.
Fuck you. [Fuck grateful. ] JONES goes. JIM continues to wash.

We only use one classroom for Jim. It’s a big one. This o only half full, is still a good crowd mixed evenly along racial and gender lines. He's a popular professor. Among students is (and this explains everything): AMY, watching him, eyes tired from her night job, her lap open. And another is DEXTER, a white, blonde stoner UCLA tennis player, a good one. Way, way, way, at the back, a ballplayer named LAMAR is checking his cellphone while his "academic advisor" is whispering to him fiercely. JIM is writing on the board “A Groats-worth of Wit, Bough with a Million of Repentance”, then, turning:
The first public notice that was ever made of Shakespeare was from a grub street writer Robert Greene, who called him an “upstart crow beautified with our feathers”. (MORE )

In the book under that title on the board. If you haven’t discovered Robert Greene on your own at this point, the man who wrote the novel Pandosto, you don’t belong in this class. ON AMY'S SCREEN is the famous picture of the ghost of ROB GREENE in his winding sheet, pen to paper at a table, condemned to hackdom even in the afterlife. She clicks an hides the picture.
(who has no idea who Robert Greene is) Is the stolen feathers thing because Greene knew Shakespeare was the Earl of Oxford? JIM puts his head on the blackboard. Not again.

Listen. The Earl of Oxford published poetry. It wasn’t any good. Had Oxford been able to get a play put on, he would have broken a leg to do it. Can you think of any human being that would for any reason not put his name on “Hamlet”? BLANK faces look at him.

The Oxfordian thing, the anti- Strafordian thing...what pisses people off about Shakespeare... What lies behind every controversy about Shakespeare...is rage. Rage over the nature, and unequal distribution, of talent. Rage that genius appears where it appears for no material reason at all. Desiring a thing... He passes AMY, walking...
.+-cannot make you have it. He drifts through the room, talking.  17.

The trouble with writing, if I may bring it up here in the English Department...instead of allowing you all to talk about sexual politics all fucking day long...is that we all do a little of it from time to time, writing, and some of us start to think, delusionally, that well, maybe with a little time, a little peace, a little money in the bank, maybe if we left the old lady and the kids, maybe if we had that room of our own, we might be writers, too. Why do we think that? We accept genius in sports, in painting, as something we cannot do, but it’s no more likely that you can be a writer than you can be an Olympic fucking pole vaulter. Because what you have to be before you try to be a pole vaulter, is a pole vaulter.
You are one.
A pole vaulter?
A novelist.

No I’m not. For me to be a novelist I'd have to make a deal with myself that it was ok being a mediocrity in a profession that died commercially in the last century. People do that. I’m not one of them. If you take away nothing else from my class, from this experience, let it be this: If you're not a genius, don’t bother. The world needs plenty of electricians and a lot of them are happy. I'll be fucked if I'll be a midlist novelist, getting good reviews from the people I give good reviews to...
You're better than—  18.

I'm not better than anybody but the people who suck. (turns, points, not going to listen to this) Let's talk about talent. Let’s have a look at Dexter right there. Dexter, an ordinary-looking young man with a size forty jacket, regular features and decent dentition, is the second-ranked collegiate tennis player in the United States. He leans in on Dexter.
How'd that come about, Dexter? You come from a tennis family?
I started five years ago in high school because the tennis guys had the best weed.

So you started playing tennis because the tennis guys had the best weed. After you started tennis, how long was it before you and everybody else realized you were better than everybody? DEXTER is well brought up and doesn’t want to answer.
Not very long. It was immediately, right? Everybody knew you were better? DEXTER nods.

What happened when you noticed you were naturally better than everybody? Everybody else is lumbering around, essentially pretending to play tennis, while you played tennis like Jesus raising the dead.
.-.-I got interested in tennis.  19.

Well, we're all different. My own personal view of Jesus is that he’d lose interest in being Jesus as soon as he realized that he was — and that it was easy. You know...how many lepers can you do without getting tired? Lazarus and water into wine are good as one- offs. I personally think that the thing to do is to one thing, definitively, and then move on...to something else...if, and only if... (and he is referring to himself) ..+.-you can figure out what it is that needs doing. But let’s deal with you. Do you remember Machiavelli? That would have been in September.
I can remember September.

Is it the game, brother, or the money? Virtu, or fama? Fame, or virtue? You're kicking ass in tennis. What are you after? Don’t go modest on me. What do you want? Money or glory? DEXTER doesn’t know what to answer.
Both?
You got ambitious, yeah? AMY is watching.
I realized...as I learned about the game, and about myself in the game, that I was in reach of the... He doesn’t want to say it. JIM leans in and whispers:
Highest possible level.
The highest level. Maybe. Yeah. That.
OK, so you're headed for the highest level. But it's not all roses. It’s still a gamble, isn’t it. Things about it burn your ass? DEXTER takes that on. Nods.

People out there writing articles about less good tennis players? You know why that is, Dexter? They have publicists. I've personally seen an article that put a fake question mark over your ability. DEXTER smolders.
Also I read somewhere that your old high school coach got a job in England claiming to have discovered and created you. DEXTER looks ready to explode thinking of that one.

Dexter's old coach now coaches the UK international team because Dexter was good at tennis. He used Dexter and fucked him. If Dexter broke his leg in five places and never played again, this guy, this fucking liar, this expatriate excrescence that came out of an alcohol coma and Pomona High School because Dexter picked up a racket because the tennis guys had the best weed, is probably going to end up knighted for services to British sport. There are two rules: first, be a genius. Second: don’t get fucked. You got that on board, Dexter, yeah? DEXTER nods.
I’m a literature teacher. I can’t write well enough to bother. (MORE)

Or I just don’t bother. Whichever. Whichever it is, there’ll be no apotheosis around here, there'll be no ambition here. I put my money down anywhere else. Because if I can't be king I won't be anybody. What did the Emperor Vespasian say on his deathbed? AMY's hand writes "Vae, puto deus fio" on her notebook an then conceals it.

He said, "Dear me, I think I am becoming a God". If I can't die knowing that I'll be remembered, I won't try to be remembered. One novel and out. If you want to learn creative writing you can go down the hall and find seven people who want to do it and can't.
You can.

But I won't. Because I'm not good enough. But do you know who does write at the highest level? When most of us, and even I, write barely adequately? Do you know who it is, in this room? The NEBBISH gets ready for coronation. JIM leans in on hi and whispers.
No, it isn’t the one who talks the most...and you really do talk shit. You don’t know anything at all. You’re an NPR host. Tops. The NEBBISH freaks. Jim indicates AMY.

The literary person here is Ms Phillips. She is the least obstreperous in this room, the quietest, and the only one in this room who can have a real career in letters. Some of you can have one perceptually. (MORE )

Only she can have one in reality. She's better at writing than our US presently amateur number two is at tennis. Let's address the Shakespeare question. Where do you come from, Ms Phillips? She is blushing furiously. Almost soundlessly:
Ohio.
Parents geniuses by any chance? Filthy rich? She shakes her head. He rounds on her like a prosecutor, brutal, blunt.
Your Dad wasn’t the Earl of Oxford was he?
No.
How old were you when you read? Almost inaudibly: Amy I was three.
That's early. That’s prodigious. Any advantages? Literary home life? She shakes her head, but is now holding his stare boldly.
What was your father?
He worked in a factory.
Your mother? AMY shakes her head. No mother, or don’t bring it up.
What was your mother.  AMY finally looks up.
She She She
turns looks does.
She was an alcoholic. She was insane. to the NEBBISH.
Isn’t your Dad...
I don’t see how this is pertinent.
(back on an uncomfortable Amy ) No money, no advantages, not a peer of the realm? You’re not the Earl of fucking Oxford are you? No? Then why the fuck are you better than the rest of us? away.
No, you look at me.
You are better than the rest of us. If no one’s told you yet that you're a genius, and an artist, let me be the first. starts to cry. goes very close to him, and into his very ear, says:
I don’t know if you can say that because I think it is subjective, man. I mean we all have something to offer.
Bullshit. He walks on: 23.  24.
Genius is magical, not material. If you don’t have the magic, no amount of wishing will make it so. The period ends. AMY in tears is gathering her stuff. To DEXTER, as he slaps him on the shoulder.
See you at the house, Shakespeare. AMY rushes from the room.

JIM is moving along, noticing AMY, who has leaned against wall to compose herself. She looks up at JIM. JIM knows exactly what he's done: some good, and he's not sure why. tears off down the hall. JIM puts his head down, and continues. DEAN FULLER falls in step beside him.
May I have a word?
More words? I've about had it with them. I don't care about words or anything else.
That's ridiculous. Jim, the athletic department—
Yes?

Has asked how a certain person is doing. He indicates the ballplayer from the classroom — a very t African American youth with a baby face who is sitting outside an advisors office (on the floor so that his heig is not absurd) talking worriedly on a cellphone. It's LAM HAMPTON.  JIM looks 25.

OK. How is a "certain person" doing? The certain person cannot write at collegiate level. Then again, who gives a fuck. Half the tenured faculty would be flogged to death for idiocy at any grammar school in any previous century.
Why do you care about that if you don't care about anything?
I probably don't care. If you want to give a dyslexic an English degree it's up to you.
It's time to get serious about your career.
When it is, I'll let you know. Unless, of course, you let me know that it's time to not get serious, and I don't care either way.
You're a born teacher. at him.
I was born a lot of things. It doesn't mean I want to be any of them. (knowing the answer) What, they got a particularly big game coming up? DEAN FULLER looks desperate and implicated.
I imagine you'd know more than anyone.

(leaning close) You don't know anything about me. But hey, I'll throw him out of class right now. He can be in academic arbitration and unable to play. Where's your money go then?  26. DEAN FULLER is the real gambler.

Oh, I'm sorry, it's already down. I'll keep him in class. Why don't you give me a call and tell me about Villanova. Quid pro quo. JIM moves on and LAMAR, on the phone, watches him pass, w interest, but continues his call. EXT. ROBERTA’S HOUSE IN BEL AIR. DAY JIM in his car waits for the GATES to open and then spins under the canopy of trees. It’s one of the more East Coas houses in Bel Air. Let it breath. Jim stops his car, sits a moment, then gets out, squinting in the California ligh He notices that: THE FRONT DOOR has been opened by a waiting BUTLER. He wa over to the front door.
Good morning Mister James.
Call me Jim. How’s the weekend.
Crap, sir.
How’d you do on the football?
Not so good.
It’s going around, brother. He passes through into the shadowed familiar interior.

text: Like the one at Evans’ house. Jim’s mother ROBERTA is pla with DEXTER, who is her coach. JIM is sitting in the high referees chair, a hat down over his eyes, smoking a cigar and watching the play.  27.
Good, good. That’s great. ROBERTA is a good older player. But can’t make the last l from Dexter. She goes to the net to shake Dexter’s hand.
I‘1l never beat you, Mister Dexter, but if you ever give me a point again, I'll fire you. DEXTER, barely sweating, grins and gets it.
Good luck in the finals.

Any money from me from now on goes directly to your wife. If I hear that you have ever touched a dime of it, there won’t be any more. Even for them. And if you don’t stop gambling, I’1ll cut them off. Don't come here for money ever again.

Did you or did you not call and ask him for more money. JIM looks over at him.
Yeah I did.

Not really but I got a junkie girlfriend and it's how I wake her up in the bathroom. The DOOR is opened on its chain, and we have a moment to the smeared unshaven face of a DEBTOR before BIG ERNIE ki the door in, breaking THE DEBTOR'S cheek in the process.

LIGHT blasts into the dark, long-term residence as THE DEBTOR, in wife-beater and underwear, reels back from the door holding his face. (to JIM) Well that's too bad, but the memories may mitigate against some pretty shitty genetics. (idly handing the dumbstruck BOY a $100 bill on the way out) Feel like a schvitz?

FRANK, who is basically Sinatra, but bald and Jewish, sit the steam, slowly shaving his head, as JIM and BIG ERNIE enter, and sit down — JIM less readily than BIG ERNIE, wh takes a covering position. JIM sits beside Frank after Fr slaps the tiles.
You have a good time with Big Ernie?
He’s not that big.

With all due respect, I’m not interested in his johnson.
Are you saying I am?

I admit that in this milieu we live in, this demi-monde, there is a little locker room humor to be expected. Locker room anything always turns out to be fundamentally, in essence, homosexual. I mean let's be frank.

I'm listening...  33.

The amount of cash you want is more than I am ordinarily disposed to loan out unless, say, you're a medium-sized country with the ability to raise taxes under the threat of military force. JIM smiles.
OR, a Eurotrash cokehead who has a father who can be squeezed after the kid’s microbudget sci-fi film doesn’t get picked up at Sundance. Are you following me? JIM nods, takes it.
You got family that can be squeezed? I’m saying that rhetorically.
Let’s deal with this as gentlemen who understand each other.
No, I need us to treat each other like we're not gentlemen and that we're very very stupid.
There’s no family. There’s never any family. FRANK accepts that.
What do you make, a hundred, hundred fifty a year? Two hundred before taxes. JIM shrugs.
What’s wrong with you? You have brain damage, some fundamental disability? Two hundred is a monk. JIM spreads his hands.  JIM nods. 34.

And you, a monk, owe that Korean son of a bitch, the prince of fucking darkness, that much right now, and then another fifty, excluding the vig, to Neville Baraka. Who will kill you because when you cut cards he got the king of spades and you laughed at him.
You're pretty well-informed.
You borrowed 50K from a very dangerous man after he was already going to kill you.
Yeah. I did.

Birth, education, intelligence, talent, looks, family money, has all this been a real comprehensive fucking burden for you? I see two problems. One, the world at his feet, in this town, and he’s a fuckin’ monk. Because, apparently, fuck it. Two, he wants to die for some unspecified personal reason and therefore owes money to Korean murderers and talks about a schwarzer’s hat in a place where you can get killed and they merely drop your body up the Angeles Crest. Three, he wants to borrow a quarter of a million dollars to pay off debts which he will not, in fact, pay off because, to go back to point two, he’s suicidal.
Just let me know what you can do for me, all right?  35.

If I help you consolidate these debts, so you don't fuck the Korean or the schwarzer up the ass, do you think that I will be anybody you want to fuck up the ass? Am I likelier to be fucked up the ass?
Less likely, I imagine.
Listen to me, listen to me, I’m not your doctor, I’m not your cognitive therapist, but let me be your uncle. You have to pay ten percent a week—
I know what I have to do.
Well, where are you going to get my money?
I’1ll get your money.
How much you want?
I'm three hundred and twenty five thousand all in, disregarding that I'm five months behind on my mortgage.
When’s the last time you ever had money in your hand to pay a debt, and paid it? JIM starts to speak. FRANK raises his hand.
Don’t fuck with me. This will be your first time when you pay. Am I right.
You're right.  36.
We're not done. I need something from you.
Collateral...what....

No, I need you to say to me “I need this money because I’m a scumbag gambler”. “I’m a scumbag gambler who takes food out of the mouths of my wife and child. That’s the kind of man I am, Frank, and I want you to loan me, a dying suicidal asshole, a lot of money”.
That’s too much to remember, to repeat it.

Lets make it simpler. I know you're not a gambler. You're doing something more complicated that manifests itself as gambling, but I don't have any other frame of reference. I've got money, you want it. If you want the money, you tell me “I am not a man”. JIM sits. He doesn’t respond.
Say it. Say “I am not a man”. We don't know whether Jim is going to say it or not and w

Students are filing out and JIM is collecting his papers putting them into his briefcase. On the blackboard we see that he has written "HCE=Here Comes Everybody". He looks and AMY is standing and looking at him. They look at each other for a long time. Then he extends a palm. She sits d in the chair. That he is in love with her is painfully obvious. That she is in love with him is apparent. It’s o of those times when you know you could cross the room. He smiles, and then doesn’t. He looks at the ceiling. Anothe moment.  37.
Yes?
Did you mean what you said? About me having talent.
I said what I said. Is there something you don’t get about “A plus plus plus, See Me?” on every JIM concedes it. He stares paper?

Yeah well I was busy and also...I didn't want to see you.
Because I’ve seen you... at her.
In your other life.
It's not another life. Anybody can see me, not see me, I don't care. There's nothing to look at. There's nothing that's going on except that I can't see you privately. She gets it.
Oh.
There it is. I don't know how to lie, so I can't talk to you.
If you're talking about having a cup of coffee or something, half the faculty...
I'm not half the faculty and I don't have a social life or a personal life, and I don't have coffee. 38. She rummages in her bag and throws his NOVEL on his desk. looks down at it.
Would you sign that for me please?
I can't. She starts to go. She does.
Please sit down.

If I've done you any good, accidentally by just telling the truth because I can't help it, I'm glad, but I’m a contaminated, suicidal fuck-up and I'm not hurting another person on the face of the earth. She indicates the novel.
I want you to sign that.
Absolutely not.
I want you to fucking sign it.
Trust me, I’m not being dramatic, but that... He pushes the book away...
...was somebody else. Who thought other things. Who lived ina different world. I cannot and will not sign it.  39.
You are being dramatic. Which is not surprising since the novel is ok but you're basically a dramatist.
Probably but who gives a fuck. Putting the book in her bag:
I didn't get to college until I was twenty five because my father died of cancer and my mother was a drunk, I'm an older undergraduate and I want to go to a restaurant.

There’s a whole bunch of things I don’t do any more. That’s kind of up there. Long silence. When he looks up, she is gone. text: JIM sits with a towel wrapped around him at the kitchen table, drinking coffee and staring into space. He looks a pile of PAPERS, loses interest. His phone rings, vibratin the yellow linoleum of the 1950s table.
Guy with no money speaking, how may I direct your call?
I’m reading your book. And he is: INTERCUT NEVILLE lying on an Empire daybed in a fantastic boudoir.  40.
Yeah? I just had a bit of a conversation about it. Long beat. Pages turn.
It’s not bad.
If you want to get into producing. There’s only about a hundred grand against it at Warner Brothers. Good script. I know the guy who did it.
It’s an indie if anything.
That’s what they thought.
I hear you went to Little Frank for money and that he wouldn’t loan it to you.
Well you heard wrong because he did try to loan it to me, and I didn’t take it.
You didn’t like the terms? And this, as we come around on Jim, is Jim’s shred of hop himself, however casually he says it:
No, the terms were unacceptable.
But you’re into me. I ain’t Fannie Mae. Ain’t no bailouts.
Why did you loan me the money?
A gamble between two players who like to play. You and me. Stakes high. You know the time frame. Tick tick tock. (MORE )
This could be good for you, brother, as a man who needs to come to his senses, but either way, you owe me. Peace out. JIM hangs up, sits for a while, and then dials a number.
I want Villanova tonight by twenty points.

(a broad swamp Yankee accent) I drink a ginger ale, it comes right out. Look at that. But I still like the taste of it. I like it here, too. I ain’t going anywhere until they come and get me. Do you know who I am?

I'm here. JIM stares through his sunglasses. JIM looks

She would.

Anybody ever wrote about you it would be half about her. No wonder you said fuck it. at the old man with great appreciation. ED (CONT’D) However, you come into this from nothing. You go back into nothing from this. So in between, you have to do what you have to do. It's the only time you got to do it. Wanted to write down what I remember. Too late. Can't do it now. Why I married your grandmother.
Tell me what you remember. ED thinks.

She said “Edward unless you stop dissipating yourself and get your elephants to Croydon I am marrying Frederick Sitwell Three.” Well I couldn’t stand the thought of that. I wasn’t going to let Fred Sitwell to get anything. How many of us succeed not because we want what we get but because we can’t be seen to lose? You sit there right now because I hated Fred Sitwell. Male behavior. Is what it is. Ladies different. Long study of subject. Been at it a hundred years now. First man to build a bridge, know what his wife said to him? JIM shakes his head, smiling. ED (CONT’D) “What are you, too lazy to row?” JIM laughs. ED (CONT’D) So because I was a jackass who had to defeat another jackass in combat there I was married almost seventy years to a woman who by and large only gave me a hard time. Got my elephants to Croydon, though. Computers then were cards. Holes in cards. Never understood it. Said I did. Invested in it.
Did you ever gamble?

No. Gambling is synthetic experience. Cowards do it. JIM gets it. And the GRANDFATHER, now looking up, isn’t a senile as he may have seemed. ED (CONT’D) There have been some calls at the office, Jim. Even on the boat.  45. THE STEWARD is glaring from the companionway.
What sort of calls. ED looks off into the marine haze.

Doesn’t matter. Whoever’s after you, you’re on your own. You'll get out of it or you won't. They sit there. ED (CONT’D) You want something to eat? EXT. JIM’S STREET. HILLS. He looks acros a NEIGHBOR, a regular middle class retired person, who is standing with a dribbling hose.
Safe is easy. You keep at it. For all of us.

Jim is in the bath eating cereal and watching a college basketball game. UCLA. A small boxy TV is balanced on a chair. In many of the shots we see, repeatedly, and we’re very close, LAMAR, his student and UCLA star. ON JIM'S face:
Oh, don't do that. We hear a ref's whistle and a roar of disapproval.
You know with some people like Adrian Mueller you just don't know what their problem is. He fouls when he has no reason whatsoever to foul.  46.
Well, either he can't help it, Chuck, or he could, but doesn't. You be the judge.
ROBERTA comes up from her car, up the walk, and knocks on door. No answer. She finds it unlocked and goes in.

JIM spoons cereal and milk, watching. The game. He looks to see: ROBERTA, dressed to the nines, looking at him. ROBERTA reaches out a foot in Manolo Blahnik and pushes t TV off the chair — there is an explosion of cathode tube, — and then sits down on the chair.
You always said you lost interest in sports after you stopped playing them.
I did. ROBERTA leaves the room and JIM, after sitting for a mome begins to get out of the bath. His feet avoid the broken glass and he whips the TV plug out of the wall.
ROBERTA is sitting agitatedly in a chair. JIM comes in, i his bathrobe, and immediately switches on the same game o the wall unit.
You have money on this game? JIM doesn’t answer. He looks back at the screen. LAMAR si a three-pointer.
He’s in my class.
Is he good at English? JIM thinks, weighs it, and then says:  47.
No.
Do you really want to be a man who goes to his mother to cover gambling debts? JIM thinks about it. He's in, if he plays it right.

Because the odds weren’t good.
How bad is the trouble you're in.
I’m always in trouble.
I mean: do you still need the money?
No.

I don’t know when to believe you anymore. (a beat) Perhaps I should believe the gangster that called my house. JIM after a complex look at his mother reaches for a pad paper and writes on it and folds it and hands it to her.
What’s this?
What I owe. She opens it and reads.
(trembling with rage; getting up) How is that possible?  48.
It was the same as marriage. I gambled, I lost.
Marriage is in the real world. It’s not a game of chance.
Now you're talking crazy. He eats cereal again. JIM looks
What will they do to you if you don’t pay? at her.
Break every bone in my body. Or go after the family. ROBERTA whacks him across the face. JIM takes it.
This isn't something you can't help. You're doing it on purpose.

There’s going to be a time when I want something again. When I won’t allow myself to be seen in this condition. But it isn’t now, and it isn’t up to you or anything you or anybody says. She sits holding the paper. Then:
Are you degraded enough to go to the bank with your mother?
JIM and ROBERTA are seated. Jim’s dignity is somewhat cov by sunglasses as he sits beside his mother.
I wish to withdraw three hundred and twenty-five thousand dollars in cash.
THE BANKER looks up.
I wish to withdraw three hundred and twenty-five thousand dollars in cash. THE BANKER looks from ROBERTA to JIM and back to ROBERTA.
In cases like this...I have to ask if everything is all right.
Nothing’s “all right” when someone needs that sort of money in cash, but it’s my money and it’s none of your business.
(to JIM) Are you a relation?
This is my son. THE BANKER takes this on.
Are you implying she’s under duress or something?
(not to be fucked with) Should I?

The money’s mine, there’s plenty of it, and please don’t tell me even once that your bullshit is for my own protection. That is understood. You have a withdrawal slip, you have my ID, I have sufficient funds, my family has been with this bank since my father started it and I need three hundred and twenty- five thousand dollars in cash. THE BANKER goes onto her computer.
You're absolutely sure you want it in cash?  EXT. BANK. 50.
Cash.
I need to get the ok of another officer.
(face burning) Do what you have to do.
ROBERTA, shaking with rage, holds the big yellow envelope money.
This is the last of it, forever. JIM is looking around at the city, as if he's not really there. JIM nods. JIM looks
If I ever have to feel the effect of your problems again, be they made up or real, or pay the consequences of your foolishness. I will never see you again. Do you understand that.

(shouting) I need you to really...fucking.. understand that. And I need you to feel like something not even human when you take this envelope. Am I just a barking dog in a silent film? What the fuck am I to you? at her.
Do you even give a damn or do you just want to take the money. Do you want to just take the money and go? Even if I say goodbye to you and consider it cheap to be rid of you?

I want to take the money and go.  51. She drops the envelope on the ground. JIM picks up the envelope. ROBERTA puts her face in her hands. Then, tough bird, she recovers herself, and races off towards her LIV CAR. WE now are watching this departure, JIM holding the money and Roberta pulling away in the back seat of her town car from the POV of a car down the street. AS JIM begins to w the car is put into gear, and begins to move slowly.

JIM, the yellow envelope on his lap, is driving through Koreatown. He passes a dubious doorway of a building containing a Korean grocery that is not really a grocery first layer of deceptive businesses that conceal the gamb establishment). There are black cars parked in front of i knot of KOREAN HEAVIES smoking cigarettes on the sidewalk JIM is agitated. He’s struggling and losing. There is a reason he doesn't want to pay.
(talking to himself, more than the driver) No no no. I don’t want to go here anymore.
This is what you said. KOREAN HEAVIES, who we recognize, have recognized JIM in back of the erratic cab.

It's not time yet. It's not time. Drive. I told you to fuckin' drive. He sits back. He looks at the yellow envelope on the seat beside him. T forward. THE KOREAN HEAVIES stare after the CAB, one of them walki into the road. EXT. JIM’S WIFE'S HOUSE. DAY The CAB drives away.  52.

JIM, holding his envelope, notes that the car is gone. He looks at the STROLLER in the corner, BEACH BAG, other obj recognizable from previous life. He uses a key on the interior door and after getting in disarms the ADT alarm. He looks around the kitchen, the h chair at the table, the washed-up bottles by the sink. He sits down at the table and with a finger turns around the baby’s placemat: it is a brightly colored map of the worl He turns it back to where it was. He goes and looks at the things stuck to the refrigerator baby pictures, but nothing of Jim. He clutches the ENVELO full of money. He continues through the house. He regards the LIVING ROO He opens a door into what used to be his STUDY and sees t the shelves are empty and the BOOKS are half put into car and half stacked on the floor by the door. He goes along and looks into the other bedroom, and when he switches on the light stands there with head cocked, looking at:

A man’s boots, a rumpled bed, two water bottles and a win glass on the night stand. He goes into the bathroom and s a leather bag of shaving tackle. Not his. He sorts throug the toilet kit and finds condoms, and, oddly, Rogaine packets. He leans against the wall and stays there, head back, eye closed, holding his crinkling envelope of money. JIM'S WIFE has put the baby in the high chair and is putt groceries away. She turns, startled, and stares. JIM stan in the doorway. JIM ignores his wife, and goes and looks at the baby. The BABY knows him: smiles, three teeth only, and those on th bottom.  53. JIM holds out his finger and the baby takes it. JIM's wife, palms on the counter, has begun to cry.

Well. We can’t really make anything you could call a plan. I can’t say have him with his hat on at the door on Friday. It’s just not like that. The house is yours. I don’t care what you do in it. He looks at the baby.
Can I pick him up? She looks at him and nods. JIM picks up the baby.

Well, buddy, at least you’re somebody's great-grandson. Exeter, Harvard, and then you’re on your own. My father fucked up. I fucked up. (to wife) When do we tell him that his paternal grandfather shot himself because he was married to my mother?

Well who should be here? Mister Rogaine? This is my child’s house.
You don’t get to say whose house it is.

There’s a male thing. You have to kind of fight it. It’s this thing called “I don’t want her but you can’t have her.” It’s responsible for quite a few marriages and most anniversaries. So I’m kinda taking that on — that, and that closet full of shitty suits. What is he some kind of salesman? A fucking salesman?  54. Furiously blushing:
He’s not a salesman. He’s in marketing... Realizing that’s the same thing, as JIM smiles:
Fuck you. Some people are just people.
I realize you might need some company around here but I’m disturbed at the stepfather idea.
Really? Enough to come home? It's real, too. JIM sits.
I can’t come home.
Why can’t you come home?
Oh, Telemachus here isn’t ready and Ithaca has a new king.

Why's his stuff in here? No, I don't care. (he suddenly attempts to hold her) I’m tired. I’m tired.
Tired?
(holding her) I always was the golden boy. I very badly needed to fuck up. Do you understand? She just looks at him. He slaps the ENVELOPE in his hands  55.
I also really needed to see some asshole’s suits in the closet. I really did. He looks at the BABY as if it is a complete enigma.
The one you're carrying now. It's not mine, is it. She shakes her head and begins to cry. JIM leaves the kitchen. He stops to kiss the baby on the head.
